channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [OAK-1034] OOME running Oak benchmark suite
item.description: Several of the benchmarks result in an OOME running with -Xmx512M

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:

CreateManyChildNodesTest on MongoMK

The issue isn't just about memory usage, but also MongoDB document size. To recap, the test creates 10'000 child nodes and calls save. This results in 40 commits to a branch, followed by a merge. Every commit contains a list of child node names because the node type is nt:unstructured and the :childOrder property is maintained with every commit. This results in very big MongoDB documents even though we now have document splitting in place. The current implementation only takes the number of commits into account to trigger a split (1000 commits). This needs to be improved to split earlier as soon as the document reaches a given size threshold.

10'000 child nodes [...] nt:unstructured

It might make more sense to adjust the test to use oak:unstructured instead, as efficiently supporting many orderable child nodes is explicitly not one of our goals.

Makes sense. Though, I wouldn't consider 10'000 that many. I think what we have in mind there is more in the area of millions of child nodes. I agree it doesn't have to be very efficient with 10'000 when there is a better alternative without orderable children, but it shouldn't run out of memory

The OOME is caused by an inaccurate size estimate for KernelNodeStates. oak-run sets the size of the kernel node cache to 100MB, but the heap dump shows twice the size.
Right, the OOME is definitely bad with 10'000 child nodes. My point was more about the performance aspect of the benchmark.

In revision http://svn.apache.org/r1526212 I implemented some improvements to speed up the test a bit with MongoMK. Together with the cache fixes the CreateManyChildNodesTest now passes but is still quite slow. 90 percentile is at one minute.

With recent changes the UpdateManyChildNodesTest runs successfully on my machine:

# UpdateManyChildNodesTest       min     10%     50%     90%     max       N
Oak-Mongo                         51      62      81     188    5196     274
Would that also apply to LinearReadEmpty? I think that is the last one with OOME.

Unfortunately not. The test still fails with an OOME in ReadManyTest.afterSuite()
when the complete test tree is removed with a single save call. This results in
a very large set of MutableNodeStates created by the commit editors. I think this
is a known issue. As a workaround we could probably change the afterSuite() to
remove the test tree in batches.
Thanks for clarifying. This is a known issue we also stumbled on while working OAK-659. See second bullet point of the respective comment .

In http://svn.apache.org/r1527935 I changed the afterSuite() method of ReadManyTest (aka LinearReadEmpty) to remove the nodes in batches. This is a workaround for OAK-1056.

Now the test runs successfully with Oak-Mongo:

# LinearReadEmpty                min     10%     50%     90%     max       N
Oak-Mongo                          0       2     108     726     838     325
